case_vignette: A 20-year-old student has an appointment with his primary care physician for an annual check-up. He is in his usual state of health. He says his sophomore year of college went well, and he’s currently been home working as a lifeguard for the summer. He asks about a good sunscreen to prevent his “sun-spots.” He reports that every summer for the last 2 years he has developed an “uneven” rash that sometimes is itchy but is otherwise asymptomatic. The rash never bothered him until recently when his friends and other pool attendees started asking if he's "peeling from a bad sunburn." His past medical history is significant for well-controlled type I diabetes mellitus. He is currently on insulin. Physical examination shows cutaneous lesions on the chest and upper extremities, which are depicted in Figure A.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have an uneven rash that sometimes is itchy but usually doesn't bother me.
How long have you had this rash?
It pops up every summer for the last 2 years.
Does the rash appear on sun-exposed areas of your skin?
Yes, it's on my chest and upper extremities.
Do you experience any other symptoms during summer, like joint pains or fatigue?
No, the rash is the only issue.
Have you noticed any blisters or is the rash just flat and discolored?
There are no blisters, just an uneven rash.
Does your rash improve or fade away when you stay out of the sun?
I haven't noticed if the rash changes when I stay out of the sun.
Do you have any personal or family history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases?
I have type I diabetes mellitus, which is well-controlled.
Are you currently on any medication, and have you used any new skin products or medications that coincide with the rash appearing?
I am currently on insulin for my diabetes, and I haven't used any new skin products or medications.
Has the rash ever been evaluated or treated by a medical professional before? If so, what was the outcome?
No, it hasn't been evaluated or treated by a medical professional before.
Final Diagnosis: Polymorphous light eruption (PMLE)
